reviews.review:
This is where it all began...

This game is fun, although having played L4D2 first, the limited amount of guns/weapons, as well as the lighting is off-putting for me. Although L4D2 is a big upgrade, the first game still remains fun.

As a foreword, I'd like to point out that despite not recommending this game, that should not imply that it's bad. Before I go any further, I'll say that the biggest reason I'm not recommending this game is because its sequel - Left 4 Dead 2 - is practically a more refined version of the same product, plus more. The second big reason is because this game's community is utterly revolting. I've met my fair share of trolls, griefers, bullies and a couple other words I can't write in this review, and it genuinely defeats one of Left 4 Dead's biggest qualities: the encouragement of cooperative play. When a game designed for four-player action becomes more appealing (and relaxing) when playing offline with the bots, there is a big problem there. I could write a whole review on why I hate L4D's community so much, but I'd rather not go there. 
Let's discuss some good things about Left 4 Dead. 
Set in October 2009, the world has been engulfed by a virus known as the Green Flu, which has turned pretty much everyone into a zombie. And I don't mean the George Romero type zombie that shambles to you at a snail's pace, I mean the rabid, snarling things from 28 Days Later. As you would expect from a game with SPRINTING zombies, Left 4 Dead is a pulse-pounding ride that holds, in my opinion, some of the most addicting game-play I've ever witnessed. It's just pure fun, and extremely gory fun at that. You make your way through abandoned environments throughout Pennsylvania that have become overrun with the infected, from ghostly metropolises, small towns, all the way to the woods of the Allegheny (a real place). Much like Valve's masterpiece game series Half-Life, Left 4 Dead employs a minimalist attitude when it comes to cutscenes and talky-talky bits, making the pace of the game very easy-going, but at the sacrifice of world-building and story-telling. The four-minute introduction that plays at the start of the game is without a doubt one of my all-time favourite game cutscenes, and what's more, it mirrors the intensity of how the game actually plays out once you take control. If that isn't a good sign I don't know what is. 
All D.L.C is completely free, which is great, though I wouldn't say you'd be missing much if you skipped them. The four protagonists are incredibly well-crafted, and have great chemistry and personality. At times they can all be downright funny too, and I still laugh out loud whenever I hear their manic laughter and death-screams. 
The weapon variety is a little bland, but this isn't really a game where it would matter all that much anyway. The special infected (smokers, boomers, hunters, tanks and witches) all unite to create a fearsome opposition for your team, and are so much fun to play as in versus mode. Beware, playing in versus is easily the most toxic aspect of this game. You will most likely be kicked for simply being a better player than the enemy team. There is also a survival mode, but it's really only about as fun and inspired as it sounds. 
As with most Valve games, a very intriguing developer commentary is included, and this is always a very awesome thing that more developers need to take note of. 
So far I have described what most would call a good game, but the big issue here is that Left 4 Dead 2 literally includes all the campaigns in this game (D.L.C included), with even more stuff added on top. For this exact reason, and in the interest of your own money, I cannot recommend Left 4 Dead. If you are curious about this series, and aren't a completionist like me, just go play Left 4 Dead 2. That game isn't perfect, but it's the complete package regardless. All in all, this game is still plenty of fun standing on its own two feet, and if you're fortunate enough to have three friends to join you, (or seven for versus) you're bound to kill some serious hours slaying the undead getting to safety. Definitely play a campaign on expert difficulty for that true survivalist experience. As an experienced player, I prefer advanced over normal difficulty - it's that sweet spot for a challenge. But like I said, go with Left 4 Dead 2. This game is better off left for... ah, never mind.

Absolute classic and such great value for money, loads of jump scares and excellent difficulty levels. I'm more of a single player and I'm still working my way through the chapters. I prefer this graphical style to photo realism, it's better than the Delta force games which I also love and will keep going back to during the holidays.
